titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Clarence Arthur Phillips (1893-1977) was a graduate of McCormick Theological Seminary and a missionary to Venezuela from 1918 to 1959. Phillips served for many years as director of the Colegio Americano de Caracas, an elementary school. Phillips also served as mission treasurer and manager of the Mission Bookstore and Press. He retired in 1959. His wife, Maude Edith Mason Phillips, was also a missionary in Venezuela. In Caracas, Mrs. Phillips taught Sunday school, trained women in house-to-house evangelism, played the organ in church, and taught music at the Colegio Americano. Clarence’s sister Verna Alice Phillips was a missionary in Venezuela from 1921 to 1954. She served as a teacher, principal and associate director of the Colegio Americano.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of Philips family papers. Materials include: daily diary, 1925, and pastor's pocket record book; photograph of teachers at the Colegio Americano, 1922; photograph album (Verna A Phillips, Venezuela) with index to pictures; scrapbook (Helen Phillips), circa 1928-1940, which includes programs, school records, correspondence, and plays; box of prints labeled Venezuela, circa 1920s-1970s, documenting the Phillips' missionary work in Venezuela; 1927 commemorative booklet on the Venezuela Misison of the Presbyterian Church in the USA; set of slides of the Interchurch Building cornerstone laying, October 12, 1958; a printed history of the Presbyterian Church in Venezuela, by Rev. C. Arthur Phillips, 1958; two small rolls of film: "Venezuela, Board of Foreign Missions, Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A” and a teaching film; lyrics and sheet music to the 1947 edition of "Himno Nacional De Venezuela,"; 1966 yearbook of the Colegio Americano; watercolor of a mission building (possibly the Colegio Americano de Caracas; scarf with Venezuela motif and box of lacework; printed histories of Venezuela; and certificates of Verna Phillips, 1953 and 1967. The collection also includes a copy of "How Many Buttons Has a Missionary," Elizabeth Irene Davenport Eggart's circa 1984 transcription with annotations of her father's (Jay Furber Davenport) diaries, 1926-1937, that document Presbyterian mission work in Venezuela.

accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted; please contact the holding institution for details.
